content:
I've edited the contribution as follows:

Goal / Output
* Removed the variable [[L]] as it's not needed

Input
* Formatted the line numbers and added "Two space-separated integers".

Output
* Changed "How many" to "Number of".

Tags
* Added the tag "Geometry".
Does Sharelock Codes use meters or feet?

I have modified the problem Statement to make it clearer and improve the English usage. I have solved and voted to approve this puzzle. Nicely done. Thank you for the fun exercise.

As an aside, this is pretty complex stuff. I don't expect the solve rate to be very high on this one. :-) Not a criticism. We need hard puzzles too.

The description is unclear:
 - how is the area surrounded? I have tried rectangular and circular and none appear to work,
 - the constraints are missing min/max ranges for X and Y,
Sorry for my english, there may be some spelling mistakes ... suggestions would be appreciated.

My assumption upon reading:

The surrounding tape doesn't correspond to any predefined shape, but is an arbitrary polygon that simply has to conform to the requirements. I haven't tried it yet, but I assume that this can be accomplished by applying Convex Hull (http://geomalgorithms.com/a10-_hull-1.html) to the set of clues, and then extending each vertex of the resulting polygon 3m directly away from the centroid of the polygon.

Okay, so I coded up a solution based on Convex Hull and extend from centroid, and that DOESN'T work, for the simple reason that it doesn't guarantee 3m distance from ALL directions of a vertex. Something a bit more sophisticated is required, like arc around each vertex, or something like that. I need to think about it some more.

This would land this puzzle in the category of extremely challenging (from my point of view) and I may not vote to approve the puzzle for a while, if ever.

After thinking about it some more, it wasn't quite as difficult as I first thought. My solution is far less elegant than that provided by mainge2036, but it comes up with the same answers. I am going to vote to approve this puzzle as-is.

Ha! After creating my solution, and posting all this, I just figured out why my solution is over-complicated. I was calculating the length of each arc at each vertex based on the angle created by the segments at the vertex. But obviously, this can be simplified. The angles should all sum to 2Ï€, so the sum of all arcs should be the circumference of a circle with radius of 3m! What a dolt! All that effort for nothing! :-) Still a nice puzzle. Thanks for making my brain hurt.

The convex-hull part was obvious to me (which means neither it ought to be obvious to anybody nor that the words "convex hull" ought to appear in the problem statement).

What seems to be missing in the text to eliminate ambiguities is that a single line of tape is to be used. Can't think of a good phrasing in the context of the problem. Had this been a Christmas lights problem, I'd say "The light strands can be plugged into one another, but you've only got one power source so the strands must form a single chain."

Take my opinion with a grain of salt, I can't seem to be able to even solve the triangle case yet ^^'

Ha ha ha. When summing distances in a polyline, sum *all* segments instead of one out of two.

All good to me (barring the slight ambiguity). Upvoted and impatiently awaiting publication.

I wasn't expecting any more updates on this one, but good show anyway! :D
I do appreciate the power of what that "single" word can do.

PS: just edited again, "feet" is the plural of "foot", not "feets".
